maori.text: Turn your face to the sun and the shadows fall behind you.
The dancing of Tanerore has begun.
The land is a mother that never dies.
The more you ask how much longer it will take, the longer the journey seems.
The ocean gives and sustain life to the worthy.
Though my present be small, my love goes with it.
Turn your face to the sun and the shadows fall behind you.
When a net is worn out, it is thrown away on the shore.
When the belly is full, the talk is good.
Land is permanent, man disappears.
Let someone else acknowledge your virtues.
Like the migrating Maruiwi, who all disappeared into the world of spirits Dead like the moa.
Many make the descent to eternal darkness but few ascend to heaven.
Many stars cannot be concealed by a small cloud.
My totara sapling so suddenly broken off.
Only the foolish visit the land of the cannibals.
Persist as resolutely as you persist in eating.
The block of wood should not dictate to the carver.
The blood of the martyrs is the seed of the Church.
A bird which eats berries can be caught, but not a bird that eats wood.
A brave man who climbs trees is food for their roots.
A whale's tooth in a whale's jaw.
A woman in the house is like a kaka in the forest.
Ask me what is the greatest thing in the world, I will reply: It is people, it is people, it is people.
Care for the land, Care for the people, Go forward.
Desolate darkeness, desolate brightness.
He who stands up will live, He who sits down will perish.
In a very old tree, you may be certain that the sapwood is on the outside, while the heartwood is in the middle.
Join those who can join sections of a canoe.
Turn your face toward the sun and the shadows will fall behind you.
Turn your face toward the sun and the shadows will fall behind you.
Turn your face toward the sun and the shadows will fall behind you.
Turn your face toward the sun and the shadows will fall behind you.
